Single-atom catalysts (SACs) are expected to be a bridge between homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis due to their high selectivity, ideal activity, stability, and reusability. The distinctive and finely tunable structure of polyoxometalates (POMs) facilitates the provision of highly homogeneous coordination sites for the active metal components, thus achieving the stable loading of a single metal atom on the supports. Due to the anchoring site, electronic, and synergistic effects, the single atoms are stabilized in POM supports, and overall catalytic performance is also improved. In this comprehensive review, the latest research progress of POM-SACs is reviewed from two aspects of design and energy catalytic application. The synthesis strategies of POM-SACs (self-assembly strategies, space confinement strategies, ion exchange methods, and others.) are comprehensively introduced. Secondly, the application status of POM-SACs in the fields of electrocatalysis, thermocatalysis and photocatalysis is emphasized. Finally, the challenges of POM-SACs in industrial applications are analyzed and the new trends for their future development are discussed. The consumption and conversion of traditional energy sources are often closely related to catalytic processes [1,2]. The types of catalytic reactions are diverse. According to the phase state (gas–liquid–solid three-phase) of reactants and catalysts, catalytic reactions can be divided into three categories: homogeneous catalysis, heterogeneous catalysis, and biological enzyme catalysis [3,4]. Since the catalytic centers of homogeneous catalysts and enzyme catalysts mostly have “isolated sites” of ligand complexation, and the reactant molecules and catalyst molecules can be in direct contact, the active center is single, so it has high activity and high selectivity [5–7]. However, enzyme catalysts can only be used under specific environmental conditions, while homogeneous catalysts are limited in their practicability due to the ease of decomposition and the difficulty of product purification, etc. Therefore, the heterogeneity of homogeneous catalysts has become one of the most important research directions in the field of catalysis [8–10]. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) have the characteristics of “independent active sites” of homogeneous catalysts and stable structure and easy separation of heterogeneous catalysts, so they are expected to become a bridge between heterogeneous catalysis and homogeneous catalysis [10,11]. In 2011, the concept of “single-atom catalytic” was proposed for the first time. Zhang et al. [12] successfully prepared FeOx-supported single-atom platinum (Pt) catalysts. It was found that the Pt single atom provided electrons to the substrate material FeOx to make the catalyst more stable and showed high activity for CO oxidation. With the development of advanced characterization techniques [13–19] and theoretical modeling [20], researchers have found that when the nanocrystal size is reduced to atomic clusters and single atoms, their energy level structure and electronic structure will undergo fundamental changes. This has led SACs to exhibit different activity, selectivity, and stability from conventional nanocatalysts [21,22]. SACs not only provide an opportunity to link heterogeneous catalysis with homogeneous catalysis but also provide an actionable platform in the study of catalytic mechanisms [23,24]. Although SACs can be used as a model for determining the active site of the reaction to achieve the study of intrinsic activity and selectivity in heterogeneous catalysis. At the same time, the real composition of the active sites of SACs involved in the catalytic reaction is still unclear because of the interaction between single metal atoms and the support and the diversity of the support. Therefore, the design of SAC models with well-defined single metal atom binding sites is extremely important for the field. An example of molecularly defined oxide supports is POMs, which are metal oxo clusters with well-defined and precisely tunable structures. Due to their easy structural modulation, good stability, acidic and redox properties, polyoxometalates (POMs) have shown promising applications in the fields of catalysis [25–27], materials [28,29], energy [30,31] and pharmaceutics [32] and have become a hot spot for multidisciplinary cross-fertilization of research. POMs provide a limited number of sites to anchor atom-dispersed metals, which facilitate the establishment of a structure–property-function relationship in catalytic reactions, and the theoretical predictions on reactivity can be verified by easily accessible model systems. Polyoxometalate-single atom catalysts (POM-SACs) offer unparalleled possibilities for unraveling the catalytic mechanism and constitutive relationships of complex catalytic systems at the atomic level [33,34]. Utilizing POM-SACs as prototypical catalysts can experimentally and theoretically solve research problems that are difficult to address with classical inhomogeneous SACs. In this review, we comprehensively summarize the synthesis strategies of POM-SACs and their applications in energy catalysis (Fig. 1 ). The discussed synthesis strategies include self-assembly strategies, space confinement strategies, ion exchange methods, and others. Additionally, we systematically review the current important applications of POM-SACs in electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, and thermal catalysis, highlighting their superior catalytic activity, stability, and selectivity. Furthermore, critical challenges hindering the industrial implementation of POM-SACs are analyzed, with emerging trends for future development comprehensively discussed. 2 Interactions between single atoms and POM supports 2.1 Anchoring site Due to the high surface energy of single metal atoms, it is often necessary to stabilize them by anchoring them at specific positions on the support to avoid aggregation under catalytic conditions. The successful formation of stable SACs strongly depends on the anchoring sites in the supports. Therefore, precise control of the anchor site is essential to achieve realistic single-atom spatial homogeneity and to further analyze the catalytic behavior [42–44]. POMs are metal-oxygen clusters with precisely known compositions and structures, which can be considered molecular analogs of solid-state metal oxides. POMs serve as ideal model systems for investigating the structure–function relationships, owing to their cluster surfaces are densely populated with oxygen species that enable precise coordination bonding of metal centers [45–47]. More importantly, POMs allow for the fine-tuning of redox properties through compositional modifications of the supporting while maintaining the geometric shape of the single-atom active site [48]. Two ways have been typically used to load metal active sites on POMs clusters. (1) Absorption. Plenary POM clusters, such as the prototype keggin anion ([XM12O40] n −), are commonly used as supports. With 36 oxygen atoms exposed, a series of coordination sites with different all-oxo coordination environments are provided on the surface of the Plenary POM anion. Here, we use X=P, M=Mo as a model: [PMo12O40]3− (Fig. 2a ). It includes the single corner site (coordination number CN=1), the bridge site (CN=2), the three-fold hollow site (CN=3), and the four-fold hollow site (CN=4) [34]. Metal active centers are generally absorbed on surface oxygen atoms of the Plenary POM anion. (2) Substitution. By selectively removing one or more “MO” units, a vacancy derivative of the Keggin anion can be obtained (so-called lacunary clusters) [49]. Using the vacancy Keggin structure POM as a “structural motif”, metal cations can be introduced at the vacancy point to synthesize metal-substituted POMs with controllable active sites. The single-atom sites are anchored through substitutional incorporation into lacunary POM anions, residing within the POM framework rather than on its surface. In both configurations, the metal sites exhibit fully exposed unsaturated coordination environments—an ideal feature for permanent monometallic anchoring—while simultaneously suppressing leaching and loss of metal centers. Pioneering work in SACs based on adsorption on the surface of the Plenary POM anion was started by Yan in 2016 [34]. They investigated and developed a Pt SAC that exhibited excellent performance and was stable in the hydrogenation reaction of nitrobenzene and cyclohexanone. The samples were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy (EXAFS), which found that Pt in Pt-PMA (H3PMo12O40)/AC (activated carbon) exists in the form of a single atom (Fig. 2b and c). The bonding interactions between Pt atoms and four bridging oxygen atoms at the fourfold hollow sites of PMA were systematically investigated via density functional theory (DFT) calculations, revealing a thermodynamically favorable coordination configuration that enhances structural stability (Fig. 2d). In recent years, systematic theoretical calculations have been widely used to study the geometry, stability, and catalytic activity of single-atom metal active sites on POM supports [37,39,50–52]. Taking the Os single atom as an example, Zhang et al. [52] calculated the free energy of its possible configuration, the results indicated that the only possible adsorption site of the Os atom was the 4-fold hollow site (Fig. 2e). In addition, DFT results suggested that due to the stronger thermodynamic driving force and enhanced N2O adsorption capacity, direct selective conversion of methane into methanol (DSCMM) activity was significantly improved on Os1/PTA SACs through a competitive but cooperative dual oxidant-based multi-functional mechanisms. In 2024, Gao et al. [53] synthesized atomically dispersed Pt-POM catalysts (Pt0.4/CsPW-H2) by deposition-precipitation method, which can efficiently catalyze the hydrogenation of 4-propyl guaiacol to cycloalkanes under mild conditions (Fig. 2f). Experimental characterization and DFT calculations cross-validated the Pt0.4/CsPW-H2 structure, indicating that Pt adsorbs in the catalyst as an Ot-Pt-Obr coordination on the 3-fold hollow site of the keggin structure of the POM (Fig. 2g). In summary, theoretical insights into the electronic structure and catalytic mechanisms of these SACs have provided fundamental guidance for advancing practical applications based on POM-SACs. Nowadays, more and more eyes have been cast on metal-substituted cavity POM-based SACs. For example, Hou et al. [54] constructed a Rh-substituted POM ionic liquid, which showed ultra-high activity (turnover frequency (TOF) > 9000 h−1) in the hydroformylation of styrene with ultra-low Rh loading (about 3 ppm) (Fig. 2h). In addition, inspired by methane monooxygenase, Ren et al. [55] used the coordination-oriented characteristics of lacunary POM clusters to accurately combine Fe metal atoms to construct a methane oxidation catalyst with clear atomic accuracy. The POM clusters are further combined with the light-absorbing semiconductor material carbon nitride (PCN) to construct a SAC with a clear structure (Fig. 2i). The Fe site with a good coordination microenvironment is conducive to an in-depth understanding of its catalytic mechanism, that is, the ingenious (WO)4-Fea(H2O)2 site in Fe-POM can form an (WO)4-Fea-Ot ··· H–CH3 intermediate with the help of H2O2 to activate the C–H bond. Thereby reducing the energy barrier of C–H bond activation and achieving efficient CH4 conversion. In brief, lacunary POM clusters have coordination guides properties that allow for the precise binding of metal atoms. Single atoms can be inserted into these lacunary POM supports with isolated binding sites, called “coordination islands”. These “coordination islands” provide a stable coordination environment, minimize the leaching of individual atoms, and can be used to tune their electronic structure. Compared with traditional nanostructured catalysts, the active sites of SACs supported on POM support are precise and uniformly distributed on the support. Each active center has the same geometric structure, which contributes to people fundamentally comprehending the catalytic mechanism of SACs, so as to have a deep understanding of single atom-substrate interaction and binding mode [35,56]. 2.2 Electron effect In the catalytic cycle, adsorption, migration, reaction, and desorption, each step involves the breaking and formation of chemical bonds. The bond breaking and formation are closely related to the electronic properties of the catalyst and the reacting substances. Due to the special position and chemical bonding on the support, the metal single atoms have unique electronic properties that are different from those of traditional metal nanocatalysts. The electronic effect between the support and the metal single atoms often affects the activity and selectivity of the catalytic reaction by changing the adsorption and desorption ability of the catalyst surface to the substrate [57]. Therefore, the study of the electronic effect between the support and the metal single atoms is particularly important to explain the superior selectivity of POM-SACs for catalytic reactions at the mechanistic level. Recently, Feng et al. [58] investigated the preparation of POM-supported rhodium SACs by self-assembly precipitation method and showed superior catalytic activity in styrene hydroformylation reaction. DFT results (Fig. 3a ) showed that Rh atoms tend to bind at the four-fold hollow site of PTA (PW12O40 3 −) clusters with a binding energy of −2.48 eV. The main reason for the large binding energy of Rh is the interaction between Rh and O atoms caused by electron transfer on the metal monoatomic Rh and PTA support. Charge density difference (CDD) (Fig. 3b) calculations confirm that there is a significant loss of electron density from Rh atoms, which flows from Rh to the nearest O atom in the POM support. In addition, the study of spin-polarized partial density of states (PDOS) (Fig. 3c) further reveals that the spin-up and spin-down PDOS of Rh-4d orbitals are asymmetric near the Fermi level, indicating that Rh has spin polarization. The presence of the Rh-4d quantum state near the Fermi level leads to high activity for small molecules and acts as an activator for adsorption in catalytic reactions. Another interesting study [33] utilized a series of structurally well-defined POM-supported Pt SACs as molecular models used to reveal the factors affecting the Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) activity of Pt SACs in electrocatalytic hydrogenolysis reactions. DFT calculations showed that differences in the Pt coordination environments lead to significant differences in the reaction pathways and energy barriers, which in turn affect the HER activity. The HER pathway shown in Fig. 3d indicates that hydrogen reduction on the PtW6 catalyst results from the combination of reactive H from the low-valent Pt center and protons from neighboring oxygen atoms. In addition, the high catalytic activity is inextricably linked to the electronic nature of the surrounding {W6O18} support. Further calculations of the hydrogen precipitation potential barriers on the surfaces of {PtW6}, {PtMo6}, and {PtSiW11} (Fig. 3e) revealed that the reactivity of these three POMs was found to be in the order of {PtW6} (0.15 eV) >{PtMo6} (0.96 eV) >{PtSiW11} (1.61 eV), with a significant difference in the energy barriers between {PtW6} and {PtMo6}. Firstly, {PtV9}, {PtMo6} and {PtW6}, which have the same coordination environments of Pt atomic sites, were selected to investigate the effect of metal oxide supports on the activity of single-atom Pt during electrochemical processes (Fig. 3f) and supported on carbon to promote electron transfer (Fig. 3 g). The results showed that even though {PtV9}, {PtMo6}, and {PtW6} have similar coordination environments at the Pt atomic sites, the different electron binding capacities of the supports lead to significant differences in HER activity. Finally, Pt atomic sites with similar tungsten oxide supports were selected to explore the effect of coordination environments on the performance of single-atom Pt HERs with different coordination environments of {PtSiW11} and {PtW6}. Fig. 3h revealed that H +connects to oxygen atoms from two different sites of {PtSiW11} and {PtW6}, respectively, wherein the {PtSiW11} W-O-Pt has a stronger affinity for protons and directly induces an H reduction potential of 1.61 eV. 2.3 Synergistic effect Strong interactions between metal single atoms and supports usually produce synergistic catalytic effects on catalytic reactions. In the meantime, different metal single atoms on the supports may have different effects on the performance of SACs. Therefore, the study of the interactions between the supports and the metal single atoms is significant for the design and preparation of new catalysts with high activity. Zhang et al. [59] quantitatively investigated the stability of Pt atoms on oxide supports and the effect of Pt-support interactions on the catalytic performance using a series of POM-supported Pt catalysts as examples. In addition, a study of their catalytic activity in catalyzing the propylene hydrogenation reaction reveals that both hydrogen and propylene are activated at the Pt single atom, whereas oxygen atoms on the supports are not directly involved in the catalytic reaction. This study shows that it is feasible to obtain highly stable SACs without affecting catalytic activity. Recently Lin et al. [60] systematically explored the reaction mechanism of POM-supported SACs M1/PTA catalyzing the fast reaction of NH3-SCR using DFT calculations. The molecular orbital diagram of Rh₁/PTA (Fig. 4a ) showed effective overlap between Rh d-orbitals and 2p orbitals of four oxygen atoms of the quadruple hollow site, with electron transfer from Rh to oxygen ligand atoms, which confirming strong metal-support interactions between the POM supports and the metal single atoms. In addition, analysis of the electron transfer mechanism (Fig. 4b) revealed that the quasi-octahedral coordination (the quadruple hollow site of the POM support + 2 NH₃ molecules) induces d-orbital distortion in Rh, lowering the energy levels of dxy and dx2-y2, narrowing the gap with NH₃’s HOMO-1 and HOMO-2 orbitals. This facilitated electron transfer from N–H bonds to Rh via orbital hybridization. Thus, the activation of NH3 by POM-supported metal SACs mainly comes from the interaction between Rh atoms and supports. And the corresponding free energy spectra and reaction mechanism diagrams of Rh1/PTA SACs catalyzing the decomposition of NH3 molecules into *NH2 and *H (Fig. 4c and d) well explain the good synergistic interactions between the Brønsted acid sites (the surface oxygen atoms in the PTA supports) and the Lewis acid sites (the single metal atoms), which effectively promote the decomposition of NH3 to *NH2 and *H. Therefore, the M1/PTA SACs catalyzed the activation of NH3 by the POM-supported metal SACs mainly from the interaction between Rh atom and support, which is the most important factor in the activation of NH3. PTA SACs have the potential for NH3-SCR reactions. With the rapid development of POM-supported SACs, more and more researchers have been interested in the synergistic catalytic effects between single metal atoms and POM supports. To gain a deeper understanding of the interactions and synergistic reaction mechanisms between metal atoms and supports, in situ/operando characterization techniques have been widely used to capture the adsorption mechanisms and electronic structure changes of single metal atoms and supports during the reaction process. Recently, Max J. Hülsey et al. [61] used a set of operando/In situ spectroscopy experiments to study the reaction mechanism of POM-supported Rh SACs in catalyzing CO oxidation. This study showed that an unconventional M-vK mechanism is followed in the Rh SAC catalyzed CO oxidation reaction and that the reoxidation of the POM support is the rate-limiting step in the CO oxidation process (Fig. 4e). The direct observation of the metal center, support, and intermediate components by this technique, combined with DFT calculations, revealed more clearly that the introduction of the metal active center can cause the formation of oxygen vacancies on the POM support. In addition, CO adsorbed on the Rh single atom can react with lattice oxygen generated by the adsorption and dissociation of O2 on the oxygen vacancies in the vicinity of POM supports in the process of CO oxidation. The above studies indicate that the interaction and synergistic catalytic effects between the metal active centers of SACs and POM supports have attracted extensive attention from researchers. Understanding the nature of the synergistic effect between supports and single metal atoms is of great significance for comprehending the catalytic reaction mechanism of POM-based SACs and designing efficient novel SACs. 3 Synthetic strategy of POM-SACs Wet chemical synthesis is the main method for preparing POMs-SACs [34,62–64]. This method provides good feasibility for large-scale manufacturing due to its simple operation. The reaction conditions used in the wet chemical method are milder and easier to control compared with other methods. In this method, metal inorganic salts or metal-organic compounds are first selected as metal precursors. Correctly combining metal precursors with solid carriers is a key step in achieving atomic dispersion. The following are several effective strategies. 3.1 Self-assembly strategy The self-assembly strategy has been widely used in the synthesis of a variety of materials, including polymers [65–68], carbon materials [68–71], biomass materials [72,73], metal oxides [74–76], noble metals [77–79], etc. By designing different nanostructures and morphologies, materials can be endowed with more excellent performance. The self-assembly strategy relies on non-covalent interactions (hydrogen and coordination bonds, electrostatic forces, van der Waals forces, etc.) to precisely control the embedding of metal atoms on POM clusters, resulting in the formation of highly ordered and stable single atom active sites [62,80,81]. To date, simple and controllable self-assembly technology has attracted much attention in the field of catalysis [82–85]. It would provide a promising and effective approach to fabricating POM-SACs with precise structure. In the initial work, He et al. [80] reported the Pd-POM SACs with Pd-substituted Wells-Dawson clusters as building blocks, which exhibited dramatic catalytic performance for Suzuki-Miyaura coupling and semihydrogenation reactions. The self-assembly of Pd-POM SACs is realized via the encapsulation of different surfactants (Fig. 5a ). EXAFS and XANES results suggested that the Pd-POM assembly is SACs, and there was only one peak at 1.5 Å from the Pd-O contribution (Fig. 5b). Subsequently, Yan et al. [62] used a self-assembly method to deposit Rh on PTA surfaces with Rh loading up to 0.9 wt%. This study showed that Rh was atomically dispersed on the pre-assembled porous POM sphere assembly, and each Rh atom coordinates with one PTA through pure Rh-O interactions with a Rh-O coordination number of 6. Liu et al. [81] demonstrated the individual POM cluster assemblies encapsulated by non-thermoresponsive ligands undergo a series of reversible morphological transitions near room temperature for the first time (Fig. 5c). This process is a reversible self-assembly of a single POM cluster guided by H-bonds. Notably, the P2W17Mn assembly can be regarded as a supported-SAC, where the Mn atoms are atomically dispersed in the structure. Moreover, due to highly ordered single-atom active sites and the special coordination state, the 2D POM superlattices show high yields and good stability in catalytic olefin epoxidation at room temperature. In 2022, Ma et al. [86] reported a facile and controllable route for the synthesis of SACs, which utilizes the non-covalent nano-assembly of supramolecular coordination complexes (SCCs) and POMs as the metal precursor, the amphiphilic PVA aerogel as the substrate to synthesize the dual single-atom catalyst (DSAC) (Fig. 5d). This method achieves high-loaded of single metal atoms by avoiding the acid etching procedure and the synergistic interaction between Zn and Mo atoms, which resulting in the dramatic performance of Zn/Mo DSAC. In recent work, Wang and colleagues synthesized attractive single-walled cluster nanotubes (SWNTs) for SACs, which are constructed from the subnanometric lacunary POM clusters (Fig. 5e) [87]. DFT calculations suggested that the frontier orbitals of POM clusters change after the metal atom is doped into the P2W17 support. The HOMO → LUMO energy gap of PtP2W17 cluster is reduced, which facilitated electron transfer between the Pt active sites and POM clusters, thereby enhancing their catalytic activity (Fig. 5f). Many POM clusters with excellent catalytic activity have been reported to anchor noble metals SAC. However, to develop high-performance POM-SACs, the assembly and structure of isolated metal sites must be precisely controlled. Self-assembly strategies can regulate precisely the assembly behavior of POM components at the molecular level, leading to isolated metal species well dispersed within the crystalline structures. Thus, the potential exists to prepare superior SACs with precise structures. 3.2 Space confinement strategy Due to the high surface energy of a single metal atom, SAC tends to undergo agglomeration coupling during the preparation and reaction process, which ultimately reduces the catalytic efficiency and leads to deactivation. Therefore, designing SACs with more homogeneous, spatially isolated, stable catalytic sites is challenging. Confining metal atoms in a nanoscale space is an effective way to prevent their migration and aggregation, which has been reported in several reviews [88,89]. In conventional wet-chemical synthesis of POM-based metallic nanomaterial, both metal precursors and POMs are simply dispersed in the liquid phase system without any spatial restriction, and it is easy to agglomerate into nanoparticles [90,91]. Liu et al. [92] developed a novel strategy for fabricating POMs-based SACs by employing metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as the finite spatial skeleton to constrain the distribution and migration of metal precursors around each POM unit (Fig. 6a ). This method can not only ensure the spatial dispersion and stability of single-atom catalytic sites but also is versatile and useful in various MOF systems. In the same year, the team successfully anchored single-atom Pd sites within POMs based pillared layer metal-organic framework (POMOFs), where the unique spatial arrangement of SiW₁₂O₄₀⁴⁻ anions created a dynamic hydrogen bond-mediated confined microenvironment (Fig. 6b) [93]. This architecture enabled selective acetylene confinement near Pd sites for efficient C₂H₂/C₂H₄ separation. The oxygen diversity of Keggin-POMs not only facilitate precise SAC anchoring [34,62], but also serve as efficient *H transport channels [87,94]. Yan et al. [95] developed a unique dual-confinement system (Fig. 6c) by encapsulating a single platinum atom in POMs and using the sub-nanopores of porous carbon (PC) for secondary confinement. Experimental and computational results show that this catalyst exhibits excellent HER activity and long-term stability in acidic media. In particular, the turnover frequency (TOF) of Pt1 @ PW12 @PC at an overpotential of 0.03 V is as high as 24.9 s−1. This study provides a general dual confinement strategy to design stable SACs and creates a well-defined model to reveal the effect of hydrogen buffering on enhanced hydrogen spillover. In recent years, as an extension of SACs, single-cluster catalysts often exhibit unexpected catalytic performance in the study of heterogeneous catalysis due to the synergistic effect between active atoms [96,97]. POMs have rich redox activity, adjustable structure, and a wide range of adjustable properties. They cannot only be used as carriers to immobilize various catalytic active centers [98,99], but also act as active sites to drive complex reactions [100,101]. However, POMs itself has high water solubility and is easy to agglomerate on the carrier, resulting in insufficient exposure to active sites, which greatly limits the comprehensive understanding of its characteristics [102–104]. Therefore, it is of great potential to construct highly dispersed single-cluster catalysts by precisely confining POMs on the support. Lu et al. [40] first reported the confined and highly dispersed polyoxometalate single clusters in covalent organic frameworks (COFs) for carbon dioxide (CO2) photoreduction. This study developed a general strategy for the uniform dispersion of POMs in COFs, that is, the POM clusters are confined in the regular nanopores of COFs by covalent bonds (Fig. 6d). The prepared COF-POM composite material combines the advantages of light absorption, electron transport and suitable catalytic active sites, and exhibits excellent catalytic activity in artificial photosynthesis. Among them, in the gas–solid reaction system, the TCOF-MnMo6 catalyst showed the highest CO yield. Recently, another interesting research has realized the stable formation of a single PMo6W6 molecule in a carbon substrate with matched pore size by using a confined strategy and activating its intrinsic activity (Fig. 6e) [105]. The confined PMo6W6 maximizes the advantages of PMo12 and PW12. Both experimental and theoretical calculations have shown that precise confinement can significantly stimulate the intrinsic redox activity of a single PMo6W6 cluster and accelerate electron transfer, which exhibited energy storage characteristics beyond a single PMo12 and PW12. 3.3 Ion exchange method Ion exchange method is a common method for preparing single atom catalysts. Usually, carriers with appropriate size and surface properties are selected to have good ion exchange capacity. The metal ions were dissolved in the appropriate solvent, then the ion exchange reaction was carried out with the carrier to form a single atom catalyst. This method can achieve precise control of the atomic distribution and composition of the catalyst. In 2021, Wang et al. [63] reported a carbon-nitrogen (CN) supported Ru1-WOx SAC that prevents Ru aggregation during pyrolysis by using a notched polyoxometalate (N-POM) (Fig. 7a ). The synthesis method first fills Ru ions into the vacancy of N-POM. Ru-PW₁₁ is immobilized onto a silica-supported anionic polymeric matrix through ionic interactions. Finally, the samples were collected and pyrolyzed at 600 °C, and the SiO2 substrate was removed by etching to obtain Ru1@WOx/CN catalyst. The catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance in the hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone (GVL) under solvent-free conditions (conversion over 99 %, selectivity close to 100 %). Recently, Zhang et al. [106] designed a nickel-substituted POM catalyst (NiPOM) based on the POM structure, which accurately replaces the central ions in the POM structure by nickel atoms to form a unique [NiO3(H2O)3] active site (Fig. 7b). Then, NiPOM single molecules were dispersed on graphene oxide (GO) nanosheets by a simple ion exchange method to form NiPOM/GO composite catalyst. This method effectively avoids the aggregation of NiPOM and highly exposes the Ni active sites (Fig. 7c). 3.4 Other synthetic strategies In addition to the above methods for preparing POM-SACs, there are other strategies, including the atomic replacement method, co-dissolution strategy, coordination orientation, etc. Yue et al. [36] successfully developed a single-atom “defect substitution” incentive strategy to obtain highly active and stable Pt-based SACs. This method uses POM (NH4)4[ZnMo6O24H6] (ZnMo6) as a template to construct a hierarchically stable system of Pt single atoms by defect substitution. In the process of in-situ conversion of Mo6 ring to Mo2C, the structure of ZnMo6 is clear, thus achieving accurate local Zn sublimation. Local defects provide a well-defined Mo(C)-Pt-N coordination environment to capture Pt single atoms (Fig. 8a ). In addition, the obtained SAC (PtSA@Mo2C@NC) exhibits excellent and stable electrochemical HER performance in 0.5 M H2SO4, with an unprecedented mass activity of 75.21 A mgPt −1. Recently, Chang et al. [99] developed a three-stage synthesis process at the air-liquid interface, providing precise control over the deposition and dispersion of platinum atoms in hexagonally filled silicate nanochannels (Fig. 8b). The excellent HER performance of the catalyst is attributed to the efficient charge transfer pathway of Pt1-PTA pairs coordinated by 4H-sites, as well as their high number density and stability in silicate nanochannels. In 2022, Wang et al. [64] explored a co-dissolved strategy to construct Pt SACs by uniformly dispersing nano [PtV9O28]7−(PtV9) clusters into [V10O28] 6−(V10) aqueous solution through freeze-drying and calcination processes (Fig. 8c). This method enables the double separation of Pt centers, effectively prevents the agglomeration of Pt centers during the high-temperature conversion process and achieves high Pt utilization during the construction of SACs. In another new study [55], a Fe (H2O)2-based POM metal cluster Fe-POM with precise structure was constructed by using the coordination orientation of absent POM (γ-SiW10), and the single dispersion of Fe-POM was realized on the carbon nitride nanosheets, and the functional carbon nitride nanosheets with clear catalytic site coordination and single dispersion were obtained (Fig. 8d). At room temperature and atmospheric pressure, Fe-POM @PCN catalyst can effectively photooxidize methane to formic acid directly, and the yield is as high as 5981.3 μmol gPOM −1, which is 3.8 times higher than that of pure POM. 4 Performance of POM-SACs 4.1 High stability Compared with conventional nanocatalysts, SACs have become a hot research topic widely used due to the highest metal atom utilization and defined activity centers. However, with decreasing size and increasing surface energy, SACs are usually highly mobile and often face the risk of agglomeration and deactivation in practical applications [107]. The unique structure of the POM clusters provides a series of coordination sites for the metal monoatoms in the event of surface oxygen leakage. In addition, the discrete POM anions can be hydrolyzed in a controlled manner, creating blank clusters and anchoring the metal active center within the POM framework. The “islands” formed by these isolated binding sites can effectively prevent atoms from clustering and leaching during preparation and catalytic reactions, which greatly improves the stability of SACs [49]. Zhang et al. [62] prepared Rh/NPTA SACs with a loading of 0.9 wt% using a self-assembly method, and the catalysts exhibited high stability in catalyzing CO oxidation reactions. The Keggin structure of PTA and the single-atom properties of Rh was well maintained after three catalytic cycles (50–400 °C). Furthermore, in a study on non-precious metal SACs in catalyzing olefin oxidation reactions, Liu et al. [108] investigated the various properties of SACs supported on POM clusters in catalytic cycling by DFT calculations. This study showed by calculating these anchoring model free energies that the most stable anchoring sites for metal atoms such as Cu, Zn, Ag, and Zn are the quadruple hollow sites on the surface of kegging-type POMs. M06L generalized function optimization of the Zn1/POM architecture (Fig. 9a ) showed that charge transfer between the Zn atoms and the POM supports occurs due to the larger contribution of the metal atoms in the five metal-based d orbitals. In addition, a comparison of the adsorption energies of the M1/POM SACs revealed that the early transition metals (Cu and Zn) have higher thermal stability. According to the energy spectrum calculated by DFT (Fig. 9b), the Zn1/POM SAC also exhibits high catalytic activity in the olefin epoxidation catalytic reaction due to its moderate energy barrier in the catalytic cycle. Recently, Li et al. [51] reported another work on the mechanism of ethylene epoxidation reaction catalyzed by PTA-supported transition metal atoms (Fe, Co, Ni, Ru, Rh, Pd, Os, Ir, and Pt) SACs. The results of DFT calculations showed that the Fe1-PTA system has adsorption energies comparable to that of the C2H4 and O2 molecules (Fig. 9c). According to the Bader charge analysis, the Fe atoms embedded in the PTA clusters are positively charged with an atomic charge of about +1.61 |e|, and massive electrons are transferred from the Fe atoms to the PTA clusters upon the Fe binding. The spin-polarized state partial density (Fig. 9d) confirms the existence of strong covalent metal-support interactions (CMSI) between the Fe-3d orbitals and the O-2p orbitals. Both the above electronic effects and strong covalent metal-support interactions lay the foundation for the high stability of Fe/PTA SACs. In summary, the stability of POM-SACs is affected by several factors, among which the charge transfer and coordination environment between the support and the metal active center are particularly important. 4.2 High activity SACs exhibit higher reactivity than conventional nanocatalysts due to maximized metal atom utilization. Compared with conventional supported SACs, POM clusters act as mediators connecting supports and single-atom sites, which can enhance the bonding with single-atom sites and thus improve the catalytic stability and activity. Ma et al. [35] constructed kegging-type POM-anchored monoatomic palladium catalysts and showed remarkable activity in catalyzing the carboxylation reaction of olefins. The conversion of styrene and the yield of carboxylic acid can reach more than 95 % at 110 °C. Under the same conditions, the POM-anchored Pd SACs showed even better catalytic activity than the conventional homogeneous PdCl2(PPh3)2 catalysts. The POM-based catalysts were characterized by UV/Vis spectroscopy, and the results proved the existence of Keggin structure in the obtained POM-anchored Pd SAC (Fig. 10a ). In situ high-pressure FT-IR analysis revealed (Fig. 10b) that an absorption peak at PdII-H appeared around 1941 cm−1, proving the existence of the Pd–H reaction pathway, which is the key to the hydroxycarboxylation reaction. The reaction mechanism in Fig.10c clearly showed that the hydroxycarboxylation reaction is carried out through the “Pd–H” pathway. In addition, the high catalytic activity also stems from the unique “pseudo-liquidity” of the catalytic system, which allows the rapid absorption of styrene molecules into the heteropolymer and makes it easier for the substrate to come into contact with the metal active center. Zhang et al. [34] prepared a single Pt-atom catalyst (Pt-PMA/AC) supported on POM for efficiently catalyzing the hydrogenation reaction of nitrobenzene and cyclohexanone. The catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity in the five cycles of nitrobenzene hydrogenation reaction, and the average TOF can be maintained at about 800 h−1. In addition, it also showed higher activity than Pt/AC in the hydrogenation of -C=O group in cyclohexanone (Fig. 10d) and phenylacetylene (Fig. 10e), and even its TOF was 6 times higher than that of Pt/AC in the hydrogenation of -C=O group in cyclohexanone. This is the first reported example of significantly higher carbonyl hydrogenation activity compared to similar metal-supported non-SACs. The reason is attributed to the unique properties of the POM, which allow charge transfer between the Pt metal atoms anchored to the 4-fold hollow site of the kegging structure and the support, and strong interactions between the metal active center and the POM support. 4.3 High selectivity POM-SACs usually exhibit high selectivity in a variety of catalytic reactions due to the unique finely tunable structure of the POMs, which facilitates the provision of a single and homogeneous coordination site for the metal active center. A number of highly active electrocatalysts for the reduction of N2 to NH3 have been synthesized, but with poor selectivity due to competitive hydrogenolysis reactions. Lin et al. [109] systematically investigated four polymetallic oxides (SiMA, SiTA, PMA, and PTA) supported single Ru atom catalysts used to catalyze the N2 reduction reaction (NRR) reaction by using DFT calculations. The results of the study showed that Ru-PTA and Ru-PMA exhibited superior NRR catalytic activity and selectivity. The preferential adsorption of nitrogen molecules or hydrogen atoms in the active site is crucial in determining the selectivity of the NRR reaction. This study showed that after applying voltage, HER will involve electron transfer to make the adsorption ΔG of *H change significantly. As a result, *H is dominant on Ru-SiMA and Ru-SiTA while N2 cannot be adsorbed and activated, while *N2 is still dominant on Ru-PMA and Ru-PTA. Therefore, Ru-PMA and Ru-PTA have good NRR selectivity. Recently, Shamraiz Hussain Talib et al. [51] systematically investigated the possible mechanisms of PTA-supported single transition metal atom catalysts for ethylene epoxidation reaction by using a first principle theoretical approach. The results indicated that in the last step of the reaction, another ethylene oxide (C2H4O) molecule with a small energy barrier of 0.28 eV is generated due to the direct interaction of the iron oxide complex with the second C2H4 molecule. The activation energy barrier of ethylene epoxidation to acetaldehyde is 1.47 eV, which led to the potential competitive pathway of acetaldehyde formation being kinetically unfavorable. Therefore Fe1-PTA showed excellent selectivity in catalyzing the ethylene epoxidation reaction to generate ethane. 5 Application of POM-SACs in energy catalytic POM-SACs, due to their well-defined active site structures, robust redox activity, and excellent metal-support synergy, have emerged as catalysts with breakthrough potential in energy and environmental catalysis. These systems demonstrate superior catalytic activity, exceptional stability, and remarkable selectivity in energy conversion systems (e.g., HER, NRR, selective methane oxidation, and water splitting for hydrogen production) and environmental remediation processes (e.g., CO oxidation and CO2 reduction), positioning them at the forefront of modern catalytic materials research. This section will systematically introduce the application of POM-SACs in the three catalytic systems of thermal drive, electric drive and light drive. For clearer and more intuitive understanding, studies on the energy catalytic applications of POM-SACs are summarized as shown in Table 1 . 5.1 Electrocatalysis 5.1.1 Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) Hydrogen is one of the ideal clean energy sources, and hydrogen production by electrolysis of water is widely recognized as an important means of achieving industrial, inexpensive hydrogen preparation [114,115]. However, industrial hydrogen production from the electrolysis of water (2H++ 2e−→H2) often requires highly active and stable catalysts due to the high overpotentials and large Tafel slopes that make the kinetics of electro-catalytic reactions slow. Yu et al. [33] selected a series of molecular models to investigate the hydrogen precipitation performance of single-atom Pt electrocatalysts, and the results showed that the HER catalytic activity of single-atom Pt electrocatalysts was affected by the dual influence of the metal-oxide supports and the coordination environment of the single-atom Pt active sites. Shamraiz Hussain Talib et al. [116] calculated the catalytic HER performance of a series of transition metals supported on PMA and showed that Pt1/PMA, Ru1/PMA, V1/PMA, and Ti1/PMA obtained near-ideal (ΔGH*=0) ΔGH* values via the Volmer–Heyrovsky pathway thus exhibiting significant HER catalytic performance. Its high catalytic activity stems from the interaction between the metal-active single atoms and the support, which allows the transfer of electrons from M1 to PMA, and demonstrates that it is feasible to achieve fast electron transfer dynamics through catalysis. In addition, a recent study provides a new strategy for obtaining high-purity H2 streams, Chang et al. [111] developed an electrothermal water-gas shift reaction system realized at room temperature. The system employed a Pd/Cs SMA to catalyze the thermal oxidation of CO and the electrocatalytic evolution of H2 at the cathode and utilized homogeneous PMA as an electronic mediator to bridge the thermal oxidation of CO and the electroreduction of protons. The reaction produces high-purity H2 (99.99 %) in the cathode chamber at room temperature. By balancing the thermocatalytic and electrocatalytic reactions, the Pd1/CsSMA exhibits excellent activity and good durability with a TOF of about 1.2 s−1 and a TTN of about 41,438 molCO2/molPd. The application of single-atom platinum cocatalysts to photocatalytic HER can achieve sustainable hydrogen energy production [117,118], and the coordination of single-atom Pt catalysts with photocatalysts is crucial for improving HER performance [119,120]. Recently, Chang et al. [99] demonstrated a 3D photocatalytic system to control precisely the deposition and dispersion of Pt atoms in hexagonal packed silicate nanochannels. The structure exhibits excellent efficiency and stability in the photocatalytic process of HER. Theoretical studies show that a single Pt atom is adsorbed on the PTA-4H site (Fig.11a ). Further evaluation of the substrate effect of SiOx shows that the critical reduction of Pt-adsorption energy to the cohesive energy close to Pt clustering is due to the interaction between PTA and silicate substrate (Fig. 11b). In addition, by adjusting the number density of PTA inserted in the silicate nanochannels, the transition of platinum atoms from aggregation to single atoms can be controlled, and the hydrogen production efficiency can be significantly improved (Fig. 11c). Furthermore, tuning and stabilizing the chemical microenvironment of Pt-based SACs is a major challenge to promote electrocatalytic HER [121–123]. Yue et al. [36] proposed a new strategy of “multistage stabilization” and prepared PtSA@Mo2C@NC catalysts by pyrolysis and introduction of Pt atoms based on organic-inorganic composites self-assembled with POMs and organic ligands as precursors. It exhibited unprecedented electrochemical HER performance in a wide pH range (Fig. 11d and e). The DFT results showed that when the Pt atoms were anchored by planar Mo2C and axial N, the electron cloud density on PtSA was significantly reduced (Fig. 11f) and migrated mainly toward the secondary support NC, which was responsible for the enhanced HER activity. This ensures that PtSA does not coalesce into Pt nanoparticles and facilitates rapid electron transfer from the Pt sites to the carriers during the HER process. In electrocatalytic HER, hydrogen spillover (H2 spillover) is considered to be the key factor in improving the efficiency of metal supported electrocatalysts. Previous studies have mainly focused on solving the problem of “overcoming large energy barriers to transfer H*”, however, the understanding of the problem of “continuous migration of H* by hindering energy accumulation” is not deep enough. Keggin-type POMs cannot only capture metal atoms, but also serve as an ideal transport channel for hydrogen. Yan et al. [95] designed a hydrogen buffer chain to assist the hydrogen spillover through the double confinement strategy, and the confined POMs became an effective H buffer chain due to their unique structure. In 0.5 M H2SO4 saturated with Ar, the Pt1@POMs@PC series catalysts exhibit an overpotential (η 10) of s than 10 mV at a current density of −10 mA cm−2, which is significantly superior to 20 % Pt/C, Pt1@PC and Pt-POMs/AC (Fig. 11 g). The excellent catalytic activity of Pt1@POMs@PC is also reflected in the small Tafel slopes, no more than 20 mV dec−1 (Fig. 11h). The experimental and theoretical results together reveal the formation of H buffer chains (Pt → Obr → O3H → Mo/W → Oc → PCsub-1-nm) (Fig. 11i and Fig. j), which can gradually buffer the energy barrier of hydrogen migration. The differential charge density distribution indicates that the Pt charge dispersion caused by POMs promotes hydrogen migration (Fig. 11k). 5.1.2 N2 reduction reaction (NRR) The electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction(N2 +6H++6e−→2NH3)is an efficient way to synthesize NH3 under mild conditions. To investigate the activity of substituted POM-SACs towards N2 reduction reaction, Wang et al. [124] used DFT to calculate the molecular geometries and possible reaction mechanisms of a series of transition-metal-substituted kegging-type POM-diazo-coordinate with molecular geometry, electronic structure and possible reaction mechanisms. The results show that the effective mixing of the σ 2s* orbitals of N2 with the dz2 orbitals of the transition metal centers due to the Jahn–Teller torsion effect makes the terminal N atoms of the N2 molecule more negatively charged relative to the bridging N atoms. Thus, this catalyst system can exhibit significant activity in the binding and activation of inert N2 molecules. NRR electrocatalysts need to overcome not only the high energy barrier for breaking N≡N bonds but also the poor NRR selectivity due to competitive hydrogenolysis reaction. Gao et al. [39] reported a novel and economical PTA-supported SACs, and it was found computationally that this type of catalysts had great inhibition of HER-selective properties at electrochemical NRR (Fig. 12a ). Further calculations of the free energy changes for the two rate-limiting steps of the first and last hydrogenation of N2 on M-PTA were performed (Fig. 12b), and the results showed that Mo-PTA (0.42 eV), Tc-PTA (0.24 eV), and Ru-PTA (0.34 eV) are more suitable for NRR. From Fig. 12c, it can be seen that N2 gains and loses roughly the same charge during adsorption and desorption, and these charge transfers clearly explain that the relatively weak interaction between NH3 and Mo-PTA allows the NH3 molecule to be readily desorbed from the active site, which facilitates the next round of NRR process on Mo-PTA. The superior catalytic performance of Mo-PTA originates from the interaction between the metal atoms and the support (Fig. 12d), and when N2 is adsorbed on Mo-PTA, the electrons are transferred to the antibonding orbitals of N2, which results in the activation of the N≡N bond. In addition, an interesting recent study reported a new strategy to modulate the performance of Mo-POM electrocatalytic NRR reaction by modulating the coordination environment of metal monoatoms through the adjustment of the central heteroatom of POM supports [125]. It was shown by DFT calculations that the charge on the oxygen atom at the 4-H site depends on the type of the central heteroatom thus leading to different electronic properties of the Mo monoatom. Fig.12e showed that more charge is transferred from the Mo metal atoms on POMs support to *N2. The resonance peak between Mo (4d) and N2 (2p) is close to the Fermi level (Fig. 12f), and the electrons are provided from the Mo atom to the N≡N bond antibonding orbital, which led to the activation of the N2 molecule. At present, the electrocatalytic NRR by most POM-based SACs is still at the theoretical research level, and further experimental investigations are needed. 5.2 Thermocatalysis 5.2.1 Selective hydrogenation reactions Selective hydrogenation is one of the important reactions in fine chemicals. Due to the maximum atom utilization and highly homogeneous active sites, SACs exhibit superior catalytic activity and selectivity in hydrogenation reactions such as hydroformylation [126,127], nitroaromatic hydrogenation, and acetylene hemihydro-genation [128,129]. However, understanding the structure-activity relationship of SACs in hydrogenation reactions remains a great challenge due to the non-uniformity of most SACs supports, which makes the coordination environment of the metal active center on the support difficult to predict. Zhang et al. [59] prepared a series of POM-supported Pt catalysts and investigated their catalytic performance in several hydrogenation reactions. The adsorption energies of Pt on four different POM supports, namely, PTA, PMA, STA, and SMA, ranged from 4.96 eV for PTA to 6.91 eV for SMA (Fig. 13a ) and the binding energy of the metal atoms Pt was estimated to be in the range of 5.5 eV. Their reactivity in propylene and butene hydrogenation reactions was systematically investigated using both experimental and theoretical methods. They found no significant difference in the activity or selectivity of each active site (Fig. 13b and c). In addition, DFT calculations showed that all the essential steps of propylene hydrogenation occurred only on Pt atoms, while the POM support acted only as anchors to the metal active sites during the reaction. This study demonstrates that structurally well-defined POM supports provide an ideal platform for studying the structure-activity relationships of SACs. Recently, an interesting study using ionic liquid-modified POM-supported SACs (i.e., (MTOA)5-[SiW11O39Rh]) could catalyze the olefin hydroformylation reaction at an ultra-low Rh loading (ca.3 ppm) [54], where Ionic liquids (Ils) not only enhanced the catalytic activity but also the anti-aggregation stability of the individual Pt atoms during the hydrogenation process. In the catalytic hydroformylation of styrene, the conversion and yield of aldehydes can reach almost 99. This is the first time that a well-defined SAC provides unusually high catalytic activity for the hydroformylation of olefins. In addition, the immobilization of POM-based SACs on IL not only results in single-atom metal catalysts with accurately isolated metal atom positions but also features heterogeneous catalysis with better dispersion in organic solvents and easy recycling. Ma et al. [35] evaluated the reusability of POM-anchored palladium SACs (Fig. 13d) for catalyzing styrene hydroxylation reactions and found that TBA-SiWPd maintained significant activity during five runs after the addition of fresh styrene, H2O and toluene (Fig. 13e). Elemental analysis of SACs after repeated reactions revealed that the palladium content of the TBA-SiWPd catalyst was very close to that of the fresh catalyst. This result confirms the catalyst's ability to stabilize the metal single atoms and its strong resistance to leaching. In addition, controlled assembly of SACs based on palladium-substituted POMs with different surfactants has also been shown to exhibit high catalytic performance in catalyzing both the Suzuki-Miyaura coupling reaction and the hemihydrogenation of alkynes [110]. In 2021, Liu et al. [93] successfully constructed a Pd single-atom site (denoted as Pd1@ Cu-SiW) inside a POM-based metal-organic framework by in-situ synthesis. This ordered spatial structure enables the catalyst to selectively adsorb acetylene from the ethylene/acetylene mixture (Fig. 13f), thereby achieving molecular sieve separation. The semi-hydrogenation selectivity of the catalyst reached 92.6 % in the case of 100 % conversion of acetylene (Fig. 13 g), and the selectivity could be maintained above 90 % in the case of continuous reaction (Fig. 13h). Subsequently, a single-atom ruthenium-embedded POM ionic liquid catalyst was successfully synthesized by simple hydrothermal synthesis and two-phase ion exchange method [130]. With the assistance of the ionic liquid 1‑butyl‑3-methyl-imidazolium acetate (BMImOAc), the amine was efficiently catalyzed to react with CO2/H2 to produce a high value-added product formamide. DFT calculations show that the substrate morpholine in the catalytic reaction can assist in the dissociation of H2 (Fig. 13k). The H‒ of the Ru5c site attacks the Cδ+ center of the CO2 molecule activated by BMImOAc (Fig. 13j), and the H+ at the N center of the morpholine electrophilic attacks the Oδ− atom of CO2 to generate formate intermediates (Fig. 13m). The N-formylation of morpholine with CO2/H2 catalyzed by Ru-POM-IL is a three-component (morpholine, Ru-POM-IL and BMImOAc) synergistic process (Fig. 13i). This synergistic effect avoids the high barrier process in the general CO2 conversion reaction (Fig. 13l), thereby achieving efficient CO2 reduction and significantly improving the reaction conversion and yield. Stabilization of metal atoms against leaching is important for POM-supported SACs in practical liquid-phase hydrogenation reactions, and combinations with ILs will be a trend for future research in designing stable, efficient, and recoverable POM-SACs. 5.2.2 CO oxidation reaction Industrial and vehicular exhaust emissions serve as the primary sources of CO pollution, where prolonged high-concentration exposure poses significant risks to human health. As such, catalytic CO oxidation has emerged as a major focus of both industrial and academic research. Furthermore, due to its simplicity of form, the CO oxidation reaction tends to be frequently used as a model probe reaction in surface catalytic studies and is widely used to explore interfacial properties of catalysts [131,132]. Several systems have been investigated to study the reaction mechanism and the factors affecting the catalytic performance of POM-based SACs in CO oxidation. In 2017, Zhang et al. [62] prepared Rh/PTA SACs with a metal single-atom loading of 0.9 wt% by a self-assembly method (Fig. 14a ). The catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity for CO oxidation in the range of 165–195 °C and maintained stability and catalytic activity after three cycles (Fig. 14b). Fig. 14c then demonstrated that Rh species exist as isolated atoms in the catalyst and are anchored in the POM quadruple neutral site, which suggests that the PTA support not only stabilizes the metal active centers but also plays an important role in catalyzing CO oxidation reactions. In particular, the reoxidation of deoxygenated PTA is a key step in the CO oxidation process. After that, Liu et al. [133] carried out further theoretical studies on the catalytic performance of POM-supported SACs for CO oxidation, the results showed that the M1/POM-catalyzed CO oxidation reaction follows the Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism. The adsorption capacity of CO on M1/PTA surface was evaluated, and it was found that CO had a strong adsorption effect on Ir, Os, Rh, Pt, and Ru (Fig. 14d). Since the Ef vac corresponding to the Oc and Ob atoms of the Pt system is relatively small (Fig. 14e), it is easier to form oxygen vacancies on the surface of the PTA carrier by removing the Oc and Ob atoms, thereby exhibiting better catalytic performance. The atomic charge changes of Pt single atoms on the two reaction paths more clearly reveal that the high catalytic activity of Pt/PTA SACs is due to the charge transfer of Pt atoms during the formation and replenishment of oxygen vacancies (Fig. 14f and g). Although the reaction mechanism of CO oxidation catalyzed by POM-SACs has been established, it is still a challenge to essentially identify which properties of the catalyst determine the catalytic activity. Therefore, it is particularly important to perform in-situ spectroscopic studies on SACs with simple structures and clear definitions to understand the role of metal active centers and carriers in the entire catalytic cycle. Through integrated in situ/operando XAS, XPS, DRIFTS, and DFT calculations, Max J. Hülsey et al. [61] revealed that the reaction mechanism of CO oxidation catalyzed by POM-supported Rh SACs follows a rather unconventional M-vK mechanism. The synergistic effect of the POM support and the metal active center significantly improved the catalytic performance. This study adds solid experimental evidence to the understanding of how CO and O2 react on monatomic active centers. In view of the fact that the complexity of the structure of most SACs supports makes the exact knowledge of the active site difficult to reach the desired level. In a recent study Max J. Hülsey et al. [134] developed electrospray mass spectrometry for the online observation of the chemical composition of the catalytic site of molecularly defined POM-supported SACs and their dynamics in the catalytic reaction. (Fig. 14h) shows that when the molar ratio of POM: Rh3+ is 1:1. Researchers observe the quantitative formation of PW11O39Rh1 4−in a solution with a seemingly complex but easily predictable cationic cladding. In addition, the mechanism of the Rh SAC CO oxidation reaction was further explored based on ESI-MS and DFT calculations (Fig. 14i), and the results indicated that the catalytic reaction was accompanied by the reduction of Rh3+ to Rh+, the formation of oxygen vacancies, and other factors related to the M-vK mechanism. This study determined the stoichiometry of the active site and the key substrate-active site complexes in the whole catalytic cycle based on ESI-MS, which provided the possibility of revealing the structure-activity relationship of SACs in the catalytic reaction with high precision. 5.3 Photocatalysis 5.3.1 Photocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (pCO2RR) Fossil fuel consumption has led to a sharp increase in atmospheric CO2 emissions, causing environmental problems such as the greenhouse effect and ocean acidification [135–137]. CO2RR has the function of reducing greenhouse gas concentration and converting it into useful products, which has broad application prospects in renewable energy storage and CO2 emission reduction [138–142]. Recent decades have witnessed remarkable advancements in catalyst development for CO2RR, with a surge of innovative strategies targeting high-performance electrocatalysts. It is worth noting that metal-based SACs have become the leader due to their maximum atomic utilization and tunable electronic structure. The rational design of supports is pivotal for optimizing SACs in CO2 reduction. POMs, comprising structurally precise nanoscale clusters, serve as versatile molecular platforms for immobilizing noble and transition metals to engineer SACs. For example, the Pt-V2O5 single-site catalyst synthesized by the co-dissolved strategy exhibited a CH4 yield of 247.6 μmol g−1h−1, which is 25 times higher than that of Pt nanoparticles on V2O5 support (Fig. 15a ) [64]. This process was accompanied by the photooxidation of lactic acid to generate pyruvic acid. In-situ FT-IR mechanistic studies (Fig. 15b) revealed that Pt-O synergism critically stabilizes the Pt-CO* intermediate. Another breakthrough involved a covalent TCOF-MnMo6 catalyst, delivering a CO production rate of 37.25 μmol g⁻¹h⁻¹ (Fig. 15c) [40]. Here, the COF-POM architecture synergistically combines CO₂ enrichment and light harvesting with MnMo₆ acting as catalytic centers. Notably, TCOF-MnMo6’s narrow 1.46 eV bandgap extends light absorption and utilization efficiency compared to ECOF-MnMo6 (Fig. 15d). DFT simulations further confirmed a photoinduced electron transfer cascade from COF to POM, driving CO2 reduction on POM and H2O oxidation on COF (Fig. 15e and f). The structure-performance relationship of active sites and their dynamic response to the environment and catalytic function are important for understanding the CO2 reduction reaction of SACs, which are frequently hard to investigate experimentally [142–145]. With the advantage of constructing well-defined single-atom sites, POMs-SACs are ideal model systems for performing computational studies to obtain atomic-level active sites and associated catalytic reaction mechanisms [37,51,52,146]. Despite progress, the mechanistic intricacies of POM-SACs in CO2RR demand deeper exploration. 5.3.2 Photocatalytic methane oxidation Methane, the primary component of natural gas, is regarded as one of the most economical fossil fuels. However, it is also a potent greenhouse gas, with a global warming potential exceeding 25 times that of CO2 [147,148]. Therefore, the catalytic conversion of methane to high value-added chemicals (such as hydrocarbons or alcohols) is of dual significance in the efficient utilization of resources and the mitigation of environmental problems [149–151]. Direct conversion of methane faces significant thermodynamic obstacles due to its non-polar molecular structure and high dissociation energy of C–H bonds. Designing high-efficiency catalysts to cross the reaction energy barrier is a key breakthrough in improving catalytic activity and directional conversion of methane. Traditional CH4 conversion processes (such as methane reforming [152] and aromatization [153]) usually face the disadvantages of harsh conditions and high energy consumption. In this context, the development of new green catalytic pathways for the direct conversion of methane to liquid oxygenates under mild conditions (normal temperature and pressure) has become a research hotspot in the cross-field of catalytic chemistry and energy chemical industry in recent years. Among emerging approaches, POM-SACs have demonstrated particular promise in photocatalytic methane oxidation. A representative example is the PMOF-RuFe (OH) catalyst reported by Yang et al. [154], which integrates three functional components: 1) a photosensitizer (PS) [RuII(bpy)2(bpydc)] (L), 2) polyoxovanadium tungstate (PW9V3), and 3) single-atom iron‑hydroxyl active sites (Fig. 16a ). This system achieves 100 % selective conversion of methane to methanol under visible light using H2O and O2, delivering a remarkable space-time yield of 8.81 mmol·gcat⁻¹·h⁻¹. Mechanistic investigations through in situ spectroscopy and theoretical calculations reveal that the single Fe site facilitates C–H bond activation via [Fe–OH–CH4] intermediate formation, while synergistic photogenerated electron transfer and radical stabilization mechanisms collectively suppress over-oxidation. Building on the demonstrated capability of POMs to enhance charge carrier dynamics in transition metal oxides (TMOs) [155–157]. Dong et al. [41] engineered a TiO2-supported catalyst featuring platinum single atoms anchored on ammonium phosphotungstate polyoxometalate clusters (NPW). This innovative design enables photocatalytic acetic acid synthesis from methane and CO at ambient temperature, utilizing water as the oxygen source. Under optimal conditions, the system produces a stable acetic acid solution (5.7 mmol·L⁻¹) with >90 % liquid-phase selectivity. Key mechanistic insights indicate that UV irradiation drives photoelectron transfer from TiO2 to Pt/NPW, while residual holes on TiO2 generate •OH radicals through water splitting. Subsequently, CO preferentially adsorbs at Pt1 sites, where •OH-mediated methane activation enables C–C coupling with adsorbed CO to form acetyl intermediates (Fig. 16b). This approach circumvents thermodynamic constraints inherent to conventional acetic acid production routes, establishing a sustainable synthesis paradigm. Notably, recent advances draw inspiration from enzymatic systems like methane monooxygenase. For instance, vacancy-engineered POM clusters have been strategically functionalized with precisely positioned Fe atoms to construct SACs for direct methane oxidation to formic acid [55]. Despite these advancements, current POM-SAC systems remain dependent on external energy inputs (light/electricity/heat). A breakthrough was recently achieved with a palladium-supported cesium phosphomolybdate catalyst (Pd/CsPMA) [158], which mediates room-temperature methane-to-methanol conversion with 67.4 μmol·gcat −1·h−1 yield and near-perfect selectivity (100 %). Structural characterization Pd atoms are anchored on the CsPMA support surface in an atomically dispersed configuration (Fig. 16c), and the redox states of the catalyst can be reversibly modulated under H₂/O₂ atmospheres (Fig. 16d). Fig. 16e demonstrates that the room-temperature hydrogen spillover phenomenon and methane oxidation activity are exclusively observed in Pd/CsPMA. Mechanistically, oxygen vacancies generated on reduced PMA surfaces spontaneously adsorb O2 to form reactive oxygen species, which abstract hydrogen from methane through a radical-mediated pathway. Crucially, Pd participates exclusively in H2 dissociation and electron transfer processes, without direct involvement in methane activation steps. This decoupled mechanism opens new avenues for directional methane conversion under energy-efficient conditions. 5.3.3 Photocatalytic water decomposition The use of solar photocatalysis for the production of H2 and O2 from water decomposition is a promising method for the sustainable provision of clean energy, and therefore the development of efficient catalysts for water decomposition is highly desirable [159–161]. POMs are a class of structurally well-defined and unique metal-oxygen clusters that are photoactive in the UV and visible spectral ranges and thus can be applied to light-driven catalytic hydrolysis reactions [162,163]. After an earlier study in which Hill et al. [112] prepared a photocatalytic water oxidizer([Co4(H2O)2(PW9O34)2]10−)with Co4 as the catalytic center, a TOF for O2 production of greater than 5s−1 at pH=8, attention was focused on light-driven water decomposition catalysts with non-precious metal active centers, such as cobalt-nickel. Lv et al. [38] reported that a tetranickel-substituted polymetallic oxoate [Ni4(H2O)2(PW9O34)2]10− (Na6K4-Ni4P2) exhibited remarkable catalytic activity in light-driven catalytic water decomposition reactions, in which the noble-metal-free complex Ni4P2 acted as an efficient and stable H2 molecule-generating under visible light irradiation catalyst. The catalyst showed almost no loss of activity after one week of catalyzing with a TON as high as 6500. Fukuzumi et al. [113] revealed the synergistic catalytic effect of single-atom metal active centers and POM supports on water oxidation in a light-driven decomposition of water to generate O2, and the results of the study showed that [RuIII(H2O)GeW11O39]5− exhibits superior catalytic activity to [RuIII(H2O)SiW11O39]5−. In addition, the modification of the internal template (there: GeO4 2−vs SiO4 2−) could modulate the interaction of SAC with pom supports. At present, light-driven hydrolysis catalysts based on heteropolyacid supporting have been reported in relatively few cases, and most of them focus on single atom-substituted POM clusters. 6 Conclusion and outlook SACs have been a hot topic in catalytic research in recent years due to the combination of the “independent active sites” of homogeneous catalysts and the structural stability and ease of separation of multiphase catalysts. POM clusters with well-defined and stable structures, which can be precisely tunable at the molecular and atomic levels, have been proven to be ideal supports for SACs. In this paper, the research progress of POM clusters-supported SACs in recent years is reviewed, the synthesis strategies of POM-SACs are summarized, and the unique roles of POM cluster supports in the anchoring of metal monoatomic and catalytic processes are investigated. Furthermore, with emphasis on the applications of POM-SACs in the fields of hydrogenation, HER, NRR, CO2RR, CO oxidation, methane oxidation, and water decomposition. Well-defined molecular modeling systems for POM-SACs provide a general platform for exploring the structure-property relationship of SACs and provide guidance for the development of novel and efficient SACs. Although significant breakthroughs have been achieved in catalysis for energy conversion and environmental remediation, research on POM-SACs remains in its early stages. We propose that the following directions warrant further exploration: (1) Dynamic site identification and characterization Although POM-SACs have been extensively studied as defined model catalysts, significant challenges persist in the precise identification of active sites and the dynamic evolution of these sites during catalytic processes. Conventional characterization methods are limited to static comparisons of POM-SACs before and after reactions, failing to capture real-time changes during catalytic processes. Therefore, there is an urgent need to employ in situ and operando characterization techniques to investigate the dynamic evolution of active sites in POM-SACs. This approach will facilitate the establishment of reliable structure-activity relationships throughout the entire catalytic cycle-from reaction initiation to catalyst deactivation. (2) Extension of multi-site synergistic catalysis Current research has predominantly focused on the single metal active site catalyst supported on POM carrier. However, these systems face challenges such as insufficient catalytic activity and limited active site diversity in tandem reactions. Future studies should expand the advantages of POM-based catalysts and characterization techniques to explore multisite cooperative catalysis involving isolated sites and clustered sites. This will elucidate the influence of distinct active site configurations on catalytic performance mechanisms, thereby guiding the rational design of advanced catalysts for complex reaction networks. (3) Improve stability In laboratory studies, activity and selectivity are common parameters for evaluating the performance of single atoms. However, the stability of single atoms is often neglected. The development of highly stable POM-SACs suitable for industrial applications is an urgent problem to be solved. (4) Machine learning (ML)and intelligent synthesis ML has emerged as a transformative tool in SACs design, particularly in accelerating the discovery and rational design of SACs with enhanced potential. In the future, extensive datasets on the synthesis and performance of POM-SACs can be systematically collected and analyzed. ML algorithms can be used to mine the rules behind the data and cooperate with high-throughput experimental screening to promote the design and development of new POM-SACs. In addition, an intelligent synthesis platform can be developed to realize the automation and precise control of the POM-SACs synthesis process and improve the preparation efficiency and reproducibility. coredata.dc:description: Single-atom catalysts (SACs) are expected to be a bridge between homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis due to their high selectivity, ideal activity, stability, and reusability. The distinctive and finely tunable structure of polyoxometalates (POMs) facilitates the provision of highly homogeneous coordination sites for the active metal components, thus achieving the stable loading of a single metal atom on the supports. Due to the anchoring site, electronic, and synergistic effects, the single atoms are stabilized in POM supports, and overall catalytic performance is also improved. In this comprehensive review, the latest research progress of POM-SACs is reviewed from two aspects of design and energy catalytic application. The synthesis strategies of POM-SACs (self-assembly strategies, space confinement strategies, ion exchange methods, and others.) are comprehensively introduced. Secondly, the application status of POM-SACs in the fields of electrocatalysis, thermocatalysis and photocatalysis is emphasized. Finally, the challenges of POM-SACs in industrial applications are analyzed and the new trends for their future development are discussed.
coredata.dc:title: Polyoxometalate-single atom catalysts (POM-SACs): synthetic strategies and energy catalytic applications
